metadata.case_name: Police Inspector (Appellant) v. State of Uttar Pradesh (Respondents)

facts.text: Appellant admitted to police force of United Provinces in 1941 as Sub-Inspector of Police.
Appellant promoted to rank of Inspector.
In 1946, appellant transferred to Anti-corruption department.
In 1947, appellant appointed to officiating rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police while retaining substantive rank of Inspector.
Complaints received by Chief Minister and Inspector-General of Police U.P. charging appellant with immorality, corruption and gross dereliction of duty.
Preliminary confidential enquiry by Inspector-General of Police found prima facie case against appellant.
Inspector-General directed formal enquiry, reverted appellant to substantive rank of Inspector and placed under suspension.
Enquiry held by Superintendent of Police, Anti-corruption department into conduct of appellant.
Report of Superintendent forwarded to Government of U.P.

Governor, under r.4 of Uttar Pradesh Disciplinary Proceedings (Administrative Tribunal) Rules, 1947, referred case to Tribunal on charges of corruption, personal immorality and failure to discharge duties properly.
Tribunal framed three charges against appellant.
Tribunal, after detailed survey of evidence, recommended dismissal on February 4, 1950.
Governor served notice to show cause why appellant should not be dismissed.
After considering explanation, Governor ordered dismissal effective December 5, 1950.
Appellant filed petition in Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari quashing Tribunal proceedings and writ of mandamus directing enquiry under s.55 Civil Services (CCA) Rules.
High Court dismissed petition on March 22, 1954.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 132.
Enquiry commenced before Constitution (Jan 26, 1950), concluded after.
Tribunal proceedings conducted in camera, no counsel for prosecution or defence.
Appellant averred prosecution conducted by Jwala Prasad (Deputy SP and Legal Advisor), but reply stated he attended only one day, no part in examination/cross-examination.
Governor considered appellant's explanation independently.
Appellant's application for summoning witnesses and records: Tribunal asked to select relevant, all summoned.
Assessor S.N. Agha absent some days, appellant gave no objection in writing.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Governor had power under s.7 Police Act to dismiss the appellant, or only Inspector-General etc.
Whether adoption of Tribunal Rules procedure instead of Police Regulations procedure violated equal protection under Art.14, as prejudicial.
Whether Tribunal proceedings vitiated by patent irregularities leading to erroneous guilt finding.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order dismissing appellant unauthorised as Governor had no power under s.7 Police Act and regulations.
Out of two alternative enquiry modes, prejudicial Tribunal mode adopted, violating equal protection.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14 Constitution; Tribunal Rules r.4 vs Police Reg.490

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal proceedings vitiated by irregularities: no lawyer for appellant while state had, explanation not considered, witnesses/records refused, assessor absent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.311(2); natural justice; Tribunal Rules r.7,10

respondent_arguments.text: Governor had power to dismiss under Police Regulations 479(a), Tribunal Rules under s.7 Police Act, preserved by Art.313.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Police Act s.7; Police Reg.479(a); Art.313 Constitution; Govt India Act 1935 s.240

respondent_arguments.text: No discrimination under Art.14: order pre-Constitution, no retrospective effect; procedures substantially same; no appeal against Governor's order in either; r.10 severable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14; Syed Qasim Razvi; Police Reg.490 cl.9; Tribunal r.7,8,10

respondent_arguments.text: No irregularities: no lawyer for either side; explanation considered; witnesses summoned as selected; assessor absence consented; no argument in HC.

court_reasoning.text: Governor had power to dismiss; s.7 not exclusive, controlled by Govt India Act/Constitution; tenure at pleasure of Governor.

Art.14 no retrospective operation; pre-Constitution order valid; post-Constitution, procedures substantially same (no hearsay, no counsel either, records/explanations similar); no appeal against Governor either way; r.10 partially invalid but severable, Governor independent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No unequal treatment; equal protection does not require identical treatment.

court_reasoning.text: No serious irregularities on affidavits: no lawyer either side; explanation considered; witnesses summoned; assessor consent.
Dissent (Das Gupta J.): Absence of appeal under Tribunal Rules vs presence under Police Reg. results in unequal treatment violating Art.14; no principle for selection.

holdings.text: Governor empowered to dismiss police officer.
Tribunal procedure not discriminatory under Art.14; substantially same as Police Regulations.

precedents_cited.case_name: Syed Qasim Razvi v. State of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-Constitution proceedings valid despite Art.14; no retrospective; post-Constitution check if discriminatory procedure actually prejudiced.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lachmandas Kewalram Ahuja v. State of Bombay
Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Content of reasonable opportunity under Art.311(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Kapur Singh v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: No discrimination if procedures not prejudicially different.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Orissa v. Dhirendranath Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Different rules with substantial differences; not applicable here as rules similar.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Disciplinary Proceedings (Administrative Tribunal) Rules, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Referral to Tribunal for specific charges; procedure; no counsel; Governor bound by recommendation (severable).

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Police Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Departmental punishment, no counsel, appeals (not against Governor).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equal protection, writs, service conditions, tenure at pleasure, protections extended to police.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Civil service tenure, special for police subordinate ranks.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed with costs by majority (Shah J.); High Court order upheld; dismissal from service valid; no violation of Arts.14 or 311; Das Gupta J. dissented on Art.14 re no appeal under Tribunal Rules.

key_quotes.text: "Equal protection of the laws does not postulate equal treatment of all persons without distinction; it merely guarantees the application of the same laws alike and without discrimination to all persons similarly situated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on Art.14 and classification.

key_quotes.text: "The primary constitutional guarantee... is one of being afforded a reasonable opportunity... discrimination is not practised merely because resort is had to one of two alternative sources of authority, unless it is shown that the procedure adopted operated to the prejudice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sardar Kapur Singh, applied to reject discrimination plea.

key_quotes.text: "While in the latter case B has some chance of the appellate authority taking a different view... A has no such chance at all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent on unequal treatment due to appeal right.
